NetScreen issued a security alert warning customers of a problem that could cause the configuration to be lost.  It is reported that the device will revert to factory settings while under heavy load and during very specific circumstances. While under heavy load, in rare occasions the device will revert to factory settings.  The specific circumstances required to replicate the condition were not described.

According to the vendor, the factory settings will provide network address translation (NAT) for all outbound traffic from the trusted interface to the untrusted interface and will reject all incoming traffic.  Because the default route will be wiped out, hosts on the trusted interface will not be able to access external networks via the device.

NetScreen has identified this as a "High" risk alert.
Impact': A remote user may be able to cause the device to reset to the factory default configuration.  This would effectively block all communications.
Solution:
The vendor has released the following fixes:

NetScreen-5XP:

4.0.0: r11
4.0.1: r4
4.0.2: r3

NetScreen-5XT:

4.0.0: r11
4.0.0-DIAL: r3
4.0.1: r4
4.0.2: r3

If you have a different release of ScreenOS, contact:

support@netscreen.com

For information on obtaining updates, see:

http://www.netscreen.com/support/alerts/03_06_03.html

Title: (SmoothWall Firewall Issues Fix) Re: Snort Intrusion Detection System Buffer Overflow in Processing RPC Messages Lets Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in Snort in the preprocessing of RPC messages. A remote user could cause arbitrary code to be executed.  SmoothWall GPL includes Snort and, therefore, is affected.
Internet Security Systems (ISS) reported that a remote user may be able to cause arbitrary code to be executed on a target Snort sensor.  The code would run with the privileges of the Snort IDS process (typically 'root' privileges).  The affected preprocessor is enabled by default, according to the report.

The flaw is reported to reside in 'spp_rpc_decode.c' and occurs during the normalization of RPC records.  The code does not properly check the length of the information being normalized against the current packet size, according to the vendor.

ISS has indicated that the remote user does not need to establish a valid connection to an RPC daemon.  A remote user can send specially crafted exploit packets via the network segment that Snort is running on to trigger the flaw.
Impact': A remote user may be able to cause arbitrary code to be executed on a Snort sensor with the privileges of the Snort process.
Solution:
The SmoothWall Project has released "fixes2 for SmoothWall GPL 1.0" to correct the flaw in Snort (which is included in SmoothWall GPL).  Information about the fix is available at:

http://www.smoothwall.org/get/download/patches/1.0-20030304-fixes2.html

According to the report, a fix was not yet available at the time of this entry for SmoothWall GPL 2.0 beta.  The report suggests that users of the beta version disable Snort from the admin configuration panel.

Title: Cisco PIX Firewall SIP Protocol Bugs Let Remote Users Deny Service
Version(s): 5.2(1) up to, but not including versions 6.2(2), 6.1(4), 6.0(4) and 5.2(9)
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Cisco PIX Firewall. A remote user may be able to cause denial of service on the firewall.
The Oulu University Secure Programming Group (OUSPG) and CERT (CA-2003-06) reported vulnerabilities in implementations of the Session Initiation Protocol (SIP), used for Voice over IP. OUSPG applied the PROTOS c07-sip test suite (http://www.ee.oulu.fi/research/ouspg/protos/testing/c07/sip/) against several vendor products to test the processing of the SIP INVITE message, used to set up sessions.

The vulnerabilities affect several vendor implementations. In general, the vulnerabilities may allow a remote user to gain access to the system or cause denial of service conditions.  However, Cisco reports only that a remote user can deny service.

Cisco reports that the PIX Firewall does not support fragmented SIP messages and may reset when a remote user sends fragmented SIP INVITE messages.  This vulnerability is documented by Cisco as Cisco Bug ID CSCdx47789.
Impact': A remote user can cause the IP Phone to reset or crash.  A manual power cycling of the device is required to return to normal operations.
Solution: Cisco has released a fix in Cisco Secure PIX Software versions 5.2.9, 6.0.4, 6.1.4, and 6.2.2 and later.

Title: Symantec VelociRaptor Firewall Buffer Overflow in RealAudio Proxy Allows Remote Users to Deny Service and Possibly Execute Arbitrary Code on the Firewall
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in the Symantec VelociRaptor Firewall appliance in RealAudio proxy and the statistics function.  A remote user can cause the proxy to crash and restart.  A remote user may be able to execute arbitrary code [but that has not been confirmed].
It is reported that Qualys discovered a flaw in the Symantec VelociRaptor Firewall.  During a vulnerability scan, the rad (RealAudio) and statsd (statistics) services reportedly terminated due to a buffer overflow.  A remote user can send malformed packets to the RealAudio Proxy to cause the proxy to restart.

SecurityFocus [owned by Symantec] reports that, although it is unconfirmed, it may be possible for a remote user to execute arbitrary code on the proxy.
Impact': A remote user can cause the proxy to restart.  This could be repeated to cause a denial of service situation.  A remote user may also be able to execute arbitrary code on the proxy [however, that has not been confirmed].
Solution:
The vendor has released a security hotfix, available at:

http://www.symantec.com/downloads/

Title: NetScreen 'Malicious-URL' Feature Can By Bypassed By Remote Users Via IP Fragmentation
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in NetScreen's 'Malicious-URL' feature.  A remote user can bypass the filter.
CIRT.net reported a flaw in the 'Malicious-URL' blocking feature.  The feature allows the firewall adminsitrator to define a malicious URL pattern that is to be blocked.  However, it is reported that if the URL in the HTTP header is split into several IP fragments, the feature can be circumvented.
Impact': A remote user can bypass the protection mechanism and access protected URLs.
Solution: The vendor has released a fixed version (4.0.1).

Title: NetScreen Predictable TCP Sequence Numbers Let Remote Users Bypass Security Rules
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in NetScreen's firewall/VPN appliances due to the generation of predicatable TCP Initial Sequence Numbers (ISNs).  A remote user may be able to hijack protected sessions or bypass the firewall's access control policies.
It is reported that a remote user can use IP spoofing and can attempt to predict TCP ISNs generated by the appliance to bypass the device's IP-based security policies.

According to the vendor, the flaw is exploitable on the following connections:

1) TCP connections to and from the NetScreen device itself
2) TCP connections that match policies requiring authentication
3) TCP connections forwarded through the appliance between two other hosts when syn-flood protection is enabled and the appliance is performing SYN proxying for the protected hosts.

According to the report, the ISN algorithms in ScreenOS 2.6 and earlier are more predictable.  However, versions all versions prior to 4.0.1 are vulnerable.
Impact': A remote user may be able to bypass the device's access control rules for certain types of connections.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fixed version (4.0.1).  NetScreen indicates that you can install one of the maintenance releases listed in their advisory (http://www.netscreen.com/support/alerts/Predictable_TCP_Initial_Sequence_Numbers.html) or upgrade to ScreenOS 4.0.1.

Registered users with a valid service contract can download the software from:

http://www.netscreen.com/support/updates.html

Title: NetScreen H.323 Session State Bug Lets Remote Users Deny Service
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in NetScreen's firewall/VPN appliances.  A remote user can prevent the firewall from processing additional sessions.
It is reported that a remote user can exploit a flaw in the processing of H.323 control sessions to cause the firewall's session table to fill up, preventing additional sessions.

According to the report, half-open H.323 sessions may remain until the defined H.323 session timeout interval (apparently this is typically 36 hours) instead of being closed out at a more frequent interval.

NetScreen reports that the system is only vulnerable if configured to permit H.323 or Netmeeting services.

NetScreen credits Stephen Gill with reporting this flaw.
Impact': A remote user can deny service to firewall users.
Solution:
The vendor has indicated that you can install a maintenance release (see the vendor advisory for the release table) or upgrade to ScreenOS 4.0.1.  The vendor advisory is available at:

http://www.netscreen.com/support/alerts/Potential_H_323_Denial_of_Service.html

Registered users with a valid service contract can download updates to:

http://www.netscreen.com/support/updates.html

Title: Cisco PIX Firewall VPN Session Management Bug Allows Man-in-the-Middle Attacks and Buffer Overflow Lets Remote Users Crash the Firewall
Description:
Two separate vulnerabilties were reported in the Cisco PIX Firewall.  A remote user with access to the encrypted stream may be able to establish an unauthorized VPN session in certain situations.  A remote user may be able to cause the firewall to crash.
Cisco issued an advisory reporting that the PIX does not delete duplicate Internet Security Authentication Key Management Protocol (ISAKMP) Security Associations (SAs) with the peer VPN entity when processing initial contact notify messages.  After a valid user establishes an authenticated VPN session, the PIX will create an ISAKMP SA associating the user with the user's IP address.  A malicious remote user that can block the valid user's connection and establish a connection to the PIX using the same IP address as that of the valid user can establish a VPN session with the PIX.  If the remote user has access to the peer authentication key (i.e., the group pre-shared key [PSK] or group password key), then the remote user's VPN session will be authenticated (via peer authentication).  Cisco has assigned Bug ID CSCdv83490 to this vulnerability.

Cisco also reported that a remote user can cause the PIX to crash due to a buffer overflow while processing HTTP traffic requests for authentication using TACACS+ or RADIUS authentication servers.  Cisco has assigned Bug ID CSCdx35823 to this vulnerability.
Impact':
A remote user with access to the encrypted traffic stream can conduct a man-in-the-middle attack against PIX VPN sessions in certain situations.

A remote user can cause the PIX to crash and reload.
Solution:
Cisco has issued the following fixed versions:

5.2.9 and later
6.0.4 and later
6.1.4 and later
6.2.2 and later

Cisco is offering free software upgrades to address these vulnerabilities for all affected customers.  See the Source Message or the Cisco advisory for detailed information about how to obtain your upgrade:

http://www.cisco.com/warp/public/707/pix-multiple-vuln-pub.shtml

Title: (Cisco Cannot Replicate the Reported Results) Re: Cisco PIX Firewall Can Be Crashed By Remote Users When In a Certain Configuration
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in the Cisco PIX Firewall.  A remote user on the local subnet may be able to cause the firewall to crash.
SecurityFocus reported a denial of service vulnerability in Cisco PIX Firewall release 6.2.2, with other versions possibly affected.

The report states that when telnet/SSH access is enabled on the firewall's internal network, a remote user on the local subnetwork can repeatedly send TCP SYN packets to the subnet address, possibly causing a denial of service condition.  No further details were provided.

SecurityFocus credits Nils Reichen <nreichen at lanexpert.ch> with discovering this flaw.
Impact': A remote user on the local subnet may be able to cause the firewall to crash.
Solution:
Cisco reported that the PIX Firewall is not RFC-compliant in responding to broadcast packets, as described in the original message [see the Message History for the original message].  This non-compliant behavior, which reportedly does not affect the security of the firewall, will be changed in a future release.

However, Cisco stated that they have not been able to confirm the denial of service issue.  Cisco indicates that they have performed additional testing under the attack scenarios described in the original message and have observed no memory leaks.

Title: (Additional Details Are Available) Re: Cisco PIX Firewall Can Be Crashed By Remote Users When In a Certain Configuration
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in the Cisco PIX Firewall. A remote user may be able to cause the firewall to crash.
It is reported that when telnet/SSH access is enabled on the firewall's internal network for at least one internal host, a remote user can repeatedly send TCP SYN packets to the subnet address of the subnet that the PIX is on, possibly causing a denial of service condition.  The firewall will respond to the TCP SYN packet, completing the TCP three-way handshaking with any external host that targets the subnet address.

According to the report, during testing with the BindView RAZOR Naptha tool (v1.1), the "show memory" command indicated that memory was decreasing over the duration of the test.  This particular test opened a TCP connection to the subnet address and never closed the connection.  During the test with one remote host acting as the attacker, the free memory was observed to be decreasing at 8 kbytes/sec.  A distributed attack could cause the system to crash.
Impact': A remote user may be able to cause the firewall to crash.
Solution:
According to the report, Cisco has assigned bug ID CSCdy51810 to this issue.  Cisco has also released a fixed version (6.2.2.111) of the PIX Firewall operating system, available via the normal Cisco update channels.  For more information, see:

http://www.cisco.com/tac

Title: Cisco PIX Firewall Can Be Crashed By Remote Users When In a Certain Configuration
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in the Cisco PIX Firewall.  A remote user on the local subnet may be able to cause the firewall to crash.
SecurityFocus reported a denial of service vulnerability in Cisco PIX Firewall release 6.2.2, with other versions possibly affected.

The report states that when telnet/SSH access is enabled on the firewall's internal network, a remote user on the local subnetwork can repeatedly send TCP SYN packets to the subnet address, possibly causing a denial of service condition.  No further details were provided.

SecurityFocus credits Nils Reichen <nreichen at lanexpert.ch> with discovering this flaw.
Impact': A remote user on the local subnet may be able to cause the firewall to crash.
Solution: According to the report, Cisco has released a fixed version (6.2.2.111) of the PIX Firewall operating system.

Title: (Vendor Issues Fix) Re: NetScreen Firewalls Can Be Crashed By Remote Users When SSH is Enabled for Remote Management
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in NetScreen's firewall products.  A remote user may be able to cause the device to crash if SSH is enabled on the device.
A remote user can send malformed messages to the SSH management port to cause the device to crash, requiring a hard reboot to return to normal operations.

The crash can reportedly be triggered by exploit utilities built to test the SSH1 CRC32 compensation attack detector code flaw that was reported in February 2001 by BindView RAZOR as a general SSH bug.  However, the vendor indicates that the NetScreen bug is not the CRC32 bug, but rather, is a new bug in their implementation.  HD Moore at Digital Defense is credited with discovering the new bug.

According to the report, SSH is not enabled by default and, when it is enabled, is usually configured for access from the trusted interface only.
Impact': A remote user can cause the device to crash.  A hard boot is required to return the device to normal operation.
Solution:
NetScreen has issued a fix and recommends that you upgrade your software or disable Secure Command Shell (SCS) administration of the device.  

If you require SCS and cannot upgrade, they advise you to enable SCS only on "trusted" interfaces.  You can also define a "manager-ip" access control list to ensure that management access is only permitted from specific trusted host source addresses.

NetScreen has is releasing maintenance releases (available now or shortly) at:

http://www.netscreen.com/support/

See the NetScreen alert for a patch version matrix to determine which version to apply at:

http://www.netscreen.com/support/alerts/11_06_02.html

Title: NetScreen Firewalls Can Be Crashed By Remote Users When SSH is Enabled for Remote Management
Version(s): Confirmed on NetScreen-25; others may be affected
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in NetScreen's firewall products.  A remote user may be able to cause the device to crash if SSH is enabled on the device.
A remote user can send malformed messages to the SSH management port to cause the device to crash, requiring a hard reboot to return to normal operations.

The crash can reportedly be triggered by exploit utilities built to test the SSH1 CRC32 compensation attack detector code flaw that was reported in February 2001 by BindView RAZOR as a general SSH bug.  However, the vendor indicates that the NetScreen bug is not the CRC32 bug, but rather, is a new bug in their implementation.  HD Moore at Digital Defense is credited with discovering the new bug.

According to the report, SSH is not enabled by default and, when it is enabled, is usually configured for access from the trusted interface only.
Impact': A remote user can cause the device to crash.  A hard boot is required to return the device to normal operation.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.

The vendor reportedly plans to release a fix shortly.

As a temporary workaround, users can disable the SSH management port until a fix is available.

Title: Symantec VelociRaptor Firewall Secure Web Proxy Lets Remote Users Cause Denial of Service Conditions
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in a component of the Symantec VelociRaptor Firewall.  A remote user can prevent users from accessing the secure web proxy.
A vulnerability was reported in a secure web server ("Simple, Secure Web Server 1.1") shipped with various Symantec firewall products.

A remote user can connect to the proxyserver and issue an HTTP-style CONNECT to a domain with a missing or flawed DNS server.  The web server will apparently wait for a timeout and will not process subsequent requests until the timeout occurs.
Impact': A remote user can cause denial of service conditions on the web server proxy.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.  The vendor is reportedly working on a patch.

Title: WatchGuard Firebox Vclass and SOHO Firewall Devices and Legacy RSSA Firewall Devices Let Remote Users Bypass the Rule Set
Version(s): Firebox SOHO firmware versions 5.1.6 and prior; Firebox Vclass/RSSA products with v3.2 SP1 and prior
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in WatchGuard's Firebox Vclass and SOHO firewall devices and legacy RSSA firewall devices.  A remote user may be able to bypass the firewall rule set.
It is reported that firewalls that support the FTP protocol without fully reassembling packets in the FTP command channel may allow remote users to bypass the firewall rule sets.  Certain WatchGuard firewalls are affected (see the Version information).

A remote user can invoke partial segment acknowledgements to cause the target FTP server to resend user-supplied control strings, causing the firewall to erroneously parse the control strings as a legitimate command and open up a hole in the firewall from the remote user to the target server.  The opened connection can apparently be used for any protocol.

A demonstration exploit transcript is provided (for a remote attack against a target server on port 5000):

Attacker: Connect to FTP server and login
Attacker: "RETR 227 Connect to me at (192,168,0,10,19,136)\r\n" [2]
Server  : "5xx No such file: 227 Connect to me at ([...])\r\n"
Attacker: Sends TCP ACK for the (here) 18 first bytes, i.e. "5xx No such file: ", NOT the whole packet, which leaves the "227 Connect to me" string in the send queue of the server. This will soon be retransmitted:
Server  : "227 Connect to me at (192,168,0,10,19,136)\r\n"

The affected WatchGuard devices will reportedly interpret the final "227 ..." string as a valid command string and will open the firewall to allow connection from the remote user's (attacker's) host to the target host on port 5000.

According to the report, it may also be possible for a malicious server to attack a client.
Impact': A remote user may be able to cause the firewall to open connections that are otherwise not permitted by the firewall rule set.
Solution:
According to CERT, WatchGuard has issued fixed versions (SOHO firmware v5.1.7 and SOHO 6 firmware v6.0.14).  Registered LiveSecurity users can download these firmware upgrades from the LiveSecurity Web site:

https://www3.watchguard.com/archive/softwarecenter.asp

For Vclass and Legacy RSSA Users, Hotfix 1 for WatchGuard Vclass v3.2 SP1 (released in July) is available.  However, the vendor recommends that Vclass and Legacy RSSA users download the more recent Hotfix 2 (Hotfixes are cumulative).  Registered LiveSecurity users can download this firmware upgrade from the LiveSecurity Web site:

https://www3.watchguard.com/archive/softwarecenter.asp

Legacy RSSA users can obtain Hotfix 2 from the Legacy RSSA software download center:

http://watchguard.com/vars/rssa.asp

Title: (Vendor Issues Fix) Re: WatchGuard Firebox Vclass and RapidStream Appliance Input Validation Bugs May Give Remote Users Root Access
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Version(s): Firebox Vclass V100, V80, V60, and V10; RapidStream RSSA 8000, 6000, 4000, 2000, 1000, and 500
Description:
Several input validation vulnerabilities were reported in the WatchGuard Firebox Vclass and (legacy) RapidStream appliances.  A remote user could gain root access on the appliance.
Several input validation holes in the firewall's commmand line interface are reported.

According to the report, a modified version of OpenSSH is used to provide remote access to the command line.  Apparently, user-supplied information is passed by this modified version to the command line interface (CLI) wrapper (/bin/cli) before authentication occurs.  Then, the CLI wrapper passes the user-supplied parameters to the CLI binary, which atttempts to peform authentication by launching "/bin/.cli -p <password>".

It is reported that there is a format string flaw in processing the password parameter, allowing a remote user to gain root access on the firewall appliance.

Also, user-supplied input is not properly validated by the CLI.  A remote user could avoid being logged out after authentication failure when a '-n' ("execute no remote command") option is used with SSH login, giving the remote user a CLI prompt with administrative privileges.

This flaw reportedly affects the current version of Vclass software, as well as legacy RapidStream appliances.
Impact': A remote user can gain root access on the firewall appliance.
Solution:
The vendor has released fixes for its Vclass line of appliances and Legacy RSSA appliances:

* Vclass 3.2 Hotfix 2, for Vclass and Legacy RSSA appliances running Vclass software

* RSSA Appliance v. 3.0.2 Hotfix 31, for Legacy RSSA appliances not yet running Vclass software

WatchGuard has provided the following instructions on how to obtain the fix:

* If you are a Vclass product LiveSecurity Subscriber, obtain this hotfix by downloading it from the LiveSecurity Web site <https://www3.watchguard.com/archive/softwarecenter.asp>  which also includes clear installation instructions in the release notes.

* If you own a legacy RSSA appliance, have already registered your product's RSSA support contract, and upgraded it to run Vclass software, please proceed to the Legacy RSSA software download center <http://watchguard.com/vars/rssa.asp>.

* If you own a legacy RSSA appliance and have not yet upgraded to Vclass software, you can download a version of the hotfix that is compatible with your current software and a copy of the release notes from the Legacy RSSA software download center <http://watchguard.com/vars/rssa.asp>

* If you own a legacy RSSA appliance and do not have a Standard or Gold RSSA support contract, please register or purchase your support contract for your RSSA product by contacting WatchGuard Support Administration Department at +1.206.521.3575 between the hours of 6:00 am and 6:00 pm Pacific Time (PST/PDT, GMT -8/-7), Monday through Friday, or via e-mail at: supportid@watchguard.com <mailto:supportid@watchguard.com>. Please have the serial number of your product(s) available when you contact them and identify yourself as a "RapidStream RSSA customer."  They will be happy to answer any questions about WatchGuard's support programs at that time.

See the Source Message for the Vendor's advisory containing additional information.

Title: WatchGuard Firebox Vclass and RapidStream Appliance Input Validation Bugs May Give Remote Users Root Access
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Version(s): Firebox Vclass V100, V80, V60, and V10; RapidStream RSSA 8000, 6000, 4000, 2000, 1000, and 500
Description:
Several input validation vulnerabilities were reported in the WatchGuard Firebox Vclass and (legacy) RapidStream appliances.  A remote user could gain root access on the appliance.
Several input validation holes in the firewall's commmand line interface are reported.

According to the report, a modified version of OpenSSH is used to provide remote access to the command line.  Apparently, user-supplied information is passed by this modified version to the command line interface (CLI) wrapper (/bin/cli) before authentication occurs.  Then, the CLI wrapper passes the user-supplied parameters to the CLI binary, which atttempts to peform authentication by launching "/bin/.cli -p <password>".

It is reported that there is a format string flaw in processing the password parameter, allowing a remote user to gain root access on the firewall appliance.

Also, user-supplied input is not properly validated by the CLI.  A remote user could avoid being logged out after authentication failure when a '-n' ("execute no remote command") option is used with SSH login, giving the remote user a CLI prompt with administrative privileges.

This flaw reportedly affects the current version of Vclass software, as well as legacy RapidStream appliances.
Impact': A remote user can gain root access on the firewall appliance.
Solution:
According to the report, WatchGuard has issued RS-302-HotFix-31 for 3.02 SP2 and Hotfix 2 for 3.2 SP1, available at:

http://watchguard.com/vars/rssa.asp

Title: (Vendor Responds) Re: Lucent VPN Firewall Brick Weakness in Processing the ARP Protocol Lets Remote Users on the Local Network Disrupt Management Communications
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Lucent VPN Firewall Brick.  A remote user on the local network can disrupt communications between the VPN Firewall Brick appliance and the management server.
It is reported that the Lucent VPN Firewall does not securely handle the ARP protocol in certain cases.

A remote user on the local network can reportedly interrupt connections between the VPN Firewall Brick and the Lucent Security Management Server.  The remote user can bind the IP address used by the Brick for management purposes to the remote user's interface and then ping the Brick management address or an address of any host protected by the Brick.  This will apparently cause the Brick to update its ARP cache and drop the existing management connection.  For this attack to work, the "Floating MAC" setting must be turned on.

It is also reported that the Brick will forward any locally generated ARP request and response across all interfaces, regardless of the existing firewall rules.

A remote user on the local network can reportedly identify a Brick by pinging all addresses in the local network segment.  The device will generate an ARP request for the remote user's IP address.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user on the local network segment can disrupt management communications.  A remote user on the local segment can send ARP requests or responses through the Brick.  A remote user on the local segment can identify the MAC address of the Brick.
Solution: Lucent has provided a response noting that the VPN Firewall Brick can be configured in a manner to avoid two of the three conditions mentioned in the original advisory.  Furthermore, Lucent plans to issue version 7.0 (planned for September 2002) to add features to further mitigate the issues described.  For details, read the vendor's response in the Source Message.

Title: Symantec VelociRaptor Firewall Appliance Uses Weak TCP Sequence Numbers That May Allow Remote Users to Hijack Sessions
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Symantec VelociRaptor firewall appliance. The firewall uses weak TCP initial sequence numbers (ISNs) that are not sufficiently random and could allow a remote user to hijack connections.
Ubizen issued a security advisory warning that the ISNs generated by the VelociRaptor firewall could allow a remote user to predict the sequence numbers for a given TCP session. According to the report, an ISN is generated based on the source and destination port and the source and destination IP address. For a single connection, the ISN will apparently stay constant for a 'long' period of time. This affects all connections to the firewall as well as connections that traverse the firewall.

A remote user could potentially hijack an existing connection to the firewall or one that traverses the firewall.

The following systems and versions are reported to be vulnerable:

Raptor Firewall 6.5 (Windows NT)
Raptor Firewall V6.5.3 (Solaris)
Symantec Enterprise Firewall 6.5.2 (Windows 2000 and NT)
Symantec Enterprise Firewall V7.0 (Solaris)
Symantec Enterprise Firewall 7.0 (Windows 2000 and NT)
VelociRaptor Model 500/700/1000
VelociRaptor Model 1100/1200/1300
Symantec Gateway Security 5110/5200/5300
Impact': A remote user could potentially hijack sessions that traverse the firewall or sessions that connect to the firewall.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fix, available at:

http://www.symantec.com/techsupp/

Title: Lucent VPN Firewall Brick Weakness in Processing the ARP Protocol Lets Remote Users on the Local Network Disrupt Management Communications
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Lucent VPN Firewall Brick.  A remote user on the local network can disrupt communications between the VPN Firewall Brick appliance and the management server.
It is reported that the Lucent VPN Firewall does not securely handle the ARP protocol in certain cases.

A remote user on the local network can reportedly interrupt connections between the VPN Firewall Brick and the Lucent Security Management Server.  The remote user can bind the IP address used by the Brick for management purposes to the remote user's interface and then ping the Brick management address or an address of any host protected by the Brick.  This will apparently cause the Brick to update its ARP cache and drop the existing management connection.  For this attack to work, the "Floating MAC" setting must be turned on.

It is also reported that the Brick will forward any locally generated ARP request and response across all interfaces, regardless of the existing firewall rules.

A remote user on the local network can reportedly identify a Brick by pinging all addresses in the local network segment.  The device will generate an ARP request for the remote user's IP address.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user on the local network segment can disrupt management communications.  A remote user on the local segment can send ARP requests or responses through the Brick.  A remote user on the local segment can identify the MAC address of the Brick.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: WatchGuard Firebox SOHO Default Configuration May Facilitate Brute Force Password Guessing Attacks on the Internal Interface
Description:
KPMG reported a potential security issue in the WatchGuard Firebox SOHO device.  A remote user can attempt to guess the FTP password to gain control of the device.
According to the report, the default configuration enables the FTP service on the internal ('trusted') interface.  The FTP service is used for firmware upgrades.  The report states that the FTP service does not require a username, allowing a remote user with access to the internal interface to conduct brute force password guessing attempts.

The following steps can be used to determine if your system is vulnerable:

ftp -n your.soho.firewall
quote pass <your password>
ls
get wg.cfg
quit

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user with access to the internal interface of the device can conduct brute force password guessing attempts via the FTP service.
Solution:
KPMG notes that the FTP service is only used when firmware upgrades are required.  So, users can disable the FTP service with the following steps to prevent bruteforcing access to the configuration file:

1) Log on to the firewall http management service
2) Select "Firewall Options"
3) Make sure there is a tick next to the field marked "Do not allow FTP access to Trusted Network interface"

Title: Cisco PIX Firewall Can Be Crashed By Remote Users Scanning the SSH Port
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in the Cisco PIX Firewall. A remote user can send certain malformed packets to the firewall to disrupt the firewall's operations or cause it to crash and reboot.
Cisco reported that this denial of service issue was introduced when the SSH code was fixed for a previously reported vulnerability (see http://www.cisco.com/warp/public/707/SSH-multiple-pub.html).

A remote user can attempt to attack the SSH port by sending large packets to cause the SSH module to consume a large amount of CPU resources, causing the device to fail to perform other tasks or to crash and reboot.  The device is only affected if SSH is enabled on the device.

A remote user can repeatedly perform an attack to cause a prolonged denial of service situation.

Cisco reports that other Cisco devices are affected, including the Catalyst 6000 switches running CatOS, Cisco IOS Routers, and Cisco 11000 Content Service Switch family. [Separate alerts will be issued for each of those platforms.]
Impact': A remote user can cause the firewall to stop performing tasks or to crash and reboot.
Solution:
The vendor has released fixed versions of the PIX software.  See the Source Message or the Vendor URL for Cisco's advisory, which contains a table listing the various PIX product release versions and the applicable fixed version.

Cisco released the following guidance regarding upgrades:

Cisco is offering free software upgrades to remedy this vulnerability for all affected customers. Customers may only install and expect support for the feature sets they have purchased.

Customers with service contracts should obtain upgraded software through their regular update channels to any software release containing the feature sets they have purchased. For most customers, this means that upgrades should be obtained through the Software Center on Cisco's worldwide website at http://www.cisco.com.

Customers whose Cisco products are provided or maintained through prior or existing agreement with third-party support organizations such as Cisco Partners, authorized resellers, or service providers should contact that support organization for assistance with the upgrade, which should be free of charge.

Customers who purchased directly from Cisco but who do not hold a Cisco service contract, and customers who purchase through third party vendors but are unsuccessful at obtaining fixed software through their point of sale, should obtain fixed software by contacting the Cisco Technical Assistance Center (TAC). In those cases, customers may only upgrade to a later version of the same release as indicated by the applicable row in the Software Versions and Fixes table.

Cisco TAC contacts are as follows:

* +1 800 553 2447 (toll-free from within North America)
* +1 408 526 7209 (toll call from anywhere in the world)
* e-mail: tac@cisco.com

Title: (Vendor Issues Fix) Re: NetScreen Firewall Can Be Made to Reboot By Remote Users That Send Long Usernames to the Device's Login Screen
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in the NetScreen 25 firewall device (which may apply to other models, as well).  A remote user that has access to the login screen can cause the device to reboot.
A remote user can apparently login to the NetScreen device with the following username to cause the device to reboot:

xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx
xxxxxxxxxxx

According to the report, the syslog log entries will only show that the NetScreen's interfaces have changed to 'Up' status.
Impact': A remote user can cause the device to reboot, interrupting all existing connections.
Solution:
NetScreen reports that this issue was discovered during internal testing and has been addressed in all versions of ScreenOS released after April 23, 2002. 

Fixed versions include: 2.6.1r8 and later, 2.8.0r2 and later, 2.8.1r1 and later, 3.0.1r2 and later, 3.0.2r3 and later, 3.0.3r1 and later.  This issue was reportedly never present in 3.1.0r1 and later.

Title: NetScreen Firewall Can Be Made to Reboot By Remote Users That Send Long Usernames to the Device's Login Screen
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in the NetScreen 25 firewall device (which may apply to other models, as well).  A remote user that has access to the login screen can cause the device to reboot.
A remote user can apparently login to the NetScreen device with the following username to cause the device to reboot:

xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx
xxxxxxxxxxx

According to the report, the syslog log entries will only show that the NetScreen's interfaces have changed to 'Up' status.
Impact': A remote user can cause the device to reboot, interrupting all existing connections.
Solution:
The author of the report indicates that the vendor has issued a fixed version (ScreenOS 3.0.1r2), but has not issued a security alert. According to the report, the release notes address the flaw (ref cs00232).

Contact the vendor for more information.

Title: SonicWALL SOHO Firewall Device Log File Filtering Hole Lets Remote Users on the Local Network Inject Scripting into Log Files for Denial of Service or Potential Cross-Site Scripting Attacks
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the SonicWALL SOHO firewall device.  A remote user on the local network can, in certain situations, inject scripting into the log files that will be executed on the administrator's web browser when the administrator views the log.
This condition can be exploited when the administrator has blocked certain web sites using the SonicWALL web blocking feature.  A remote user on the local network can issue an HTTP GET request for a "blocked list" URL, where the HTTP request also contains scripting in the URL. An example of this format is provided:

http://[blockedhost]/<SCRIPT>[script_goes_here]</SCRIPT>

The user-supplied URL will be entered into the log file.  Then, when an administrator attempts to view the log file, the script will be executed by the administrator's browser.  If the script includes a redirect, for example, the administrator's browser will be redirected and the administrator will not be able to view the log file (if scripting is enabled).

[Editors' note:  It may be possible that this exploit method can be used to cause the administrator's browser to take firewall management actions on behalf of the administrator, however, this was not confirmed in the report.]
Impact': A remote user can cause arbitrary scripting code to be executed by the administrator's browser when the administrator views the log file.  It may be possible for this code to take firewall administrator actions on behalf of the administrator, but that was not confirmed.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.

It appears that SonicWALL requires Javascript to be enabled on the administrator's browser inorder for the administrator to login.  However, it also appears that Javascript is not required to view the log file.  If so, then the administrator can disable Javascript before viewing the log file to determine which host injected the malicious scripting code.

Title: SnapGear LITE+ Firewall Device Can Be Crashed By Remote Users Sending Certain Malformed Packets or Consuming Connections on Management Ports
Description:
KPMG reported a denial of service vulnerability in the SnapGear LITE+ firewall device.  A remote user can cause the device to crash.
It is reported that the firewall does not properly process malformed packets on several ports.

A remote user can create 50 TCP connections to the external web management port (if it is enabled) to cause the firewall to crash.  In version 1.5.4, the result would reportedly be that the web management port crashes instead of the entire device.

A remote user can use the same technique against the PPTP port (if enabled) to cause the same effect.

A remote user can send a 0 length UDP packet to UDP port 500 to cause the IPSec functions to stop working (this affects version 1.5.3 only).

A remote user can send a stream of approximately 7000 packets with malformed IP options through the firewall to cause the firewall to crash.
Impact': A remote user can cause the firewall device to crash.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fixed version (1.6.0), available at:

http://www.snapgear.com/downloads.html

Title: WatchGuard Firebox SOHO Firewall May Fail to Apply IP-based Access Restrictions Under Certain Circumstances
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the WatchGuard Firebox SOHO firewall device.  A remote user could gain access to services ostensibly protected by the firewall using IP restrictions.
It is reported that, under certain circumstances, IP restrictions on customised services could be inadvertently turned off.  If a firewall administrator has configured IP restrictions and then upgrades to version 5.0.35 (which corrected previously reported issues with TCP/IP handling on port-forwarding), it is reported that the IP restrictions may fail without notice.
Impact': A remote user may be able to access restricted hosts through the firewall.
Solution: The vendor has released a fix.  Upgrade to firmware version 5.0.35a, available through Watchguard Livesecurity.

Title: WatchGuard Firebox SOHO IP Options Processing Bug Lets Remote Users Crash the Firewall When in a Certain Configuration
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in WatchGuard's Firebox SOHO firewall appliance.  A remote user can cause the firewall to crash and reboot when in a certain configuration.
A remote user can reportedly send IP packets with certain malformed IP options to the Firebox SOHO firewall to cause it to crash and reboot.  This will apparently cause current connections, including VPN connections, to drop.

According to the report, the vulnerability is exposed when the firewall is configured to perform IP packet forwarding and, because of that, must parse the IP options.
Impact': A remote user can cause the firewall appliance to crash and reboot, dropping all connections.  This apparently can only occur when the firewall is configured to forward IP packets.
Solution: The vendor has reportedly released a fixed version of the firmware (5.0.35).  Contact the vendor to obtain the update.

Title: ZyXEL ZyWALL Security Gateway ARP Processing Bug Lets Users on the Local Network Cause the Security Gateway's Interface to Go Down
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in ZyXEL's ZyWALL 10 security gateway device.  A remote user with access to the local network can cause an interface on the device to crash.
A remote user with access to the local network can send an arp packet containing a bogus Ethernet MAC address associated with the security gateway's own IP address to the security gateway's LAN interface to cause the interface to go down.  A powercycle plus administrator console interaction is reportedly required for the device to return to normal operations.

The following nemesis-arp utility command will reportedly trigger the vulnerability:

nemesis-arp -S 10.0.0.1 -D 10.0.0.1 -h de:ad:ba:be:f0:0d -d ed1 

(where the gateway's IP is 10.0.0.1 and the ethernet adapter is ed1)
Impact': A remote user with access to the local area network can cause the device to crash.
Solution: The vendor has reportedly released a fix.  Contact the vendor for the fix.

Title: (Vendor Provides a Response Detailing Product Protection Mechanisms) Re: NetScreen Firewalls Can Be Made Unresponsive By a Remote User on the Trusted Interface Side Conducting Port Scans Through the Firewall
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in NetScreen firewalls (Screen OS).  A remote user on the trusted interface can cause the interface to hang.
In the original Alert (see the Message History), it is reported that a remote user on the trusted (internal) interface can conduct a port scan on an external IP address to consume available sessions on the firewall. This can reportedly cause the entire trusted interface to become unresponsive.

The vendor has provided a response (see the Source Message) that details the potential vulnerability and describes the protection mechanisms that have been available in NetScreen since September 2001.
Impact': A remote user on the internal (trusted) interface can cause the interface to become unresponsive.
Solution:
The vendor reports that features to address this issue in several manners were relased in September 2001:

"One feature called Source IP Session Thresholding can be used to mitigate the likelihood of this issue arising in the first place.  This feature was introduced as a CLI command in ScreenOS version 2.6.1r2, and has been incorporated into the WebUI starting with ScreenOS version 3.0.  

The command

set firewall session-threshold source-ip-based [num]

limits any one source IP from the trusted side to [num] number of concurrent sessions.  Since the NetScreen-5XP can support 2,048 concurrent sessions, NetScreen recommends the higher of the following two numbers as a starting point:  100, or 2048/n where "n" is the number of systems on the "Trust" side network.  Administrators are advised to check their flow counters to see if that's an acceptable number, and modify accordingly.

Next, releases of ScreenOS 3.0.0 and later allow the administrator to forcibly clear sessions based on characteristics of those sessions such as source IP address, destination IP address, source port, destination port, source MAC address, and/or destination MAC address.

For example, the command

clear session dst-ip <a.b.c.d>

will clear all active sessions to destination IP address a.b.c.d from the NetScreen active session table. This command can be used to recover from a wild port scan without waiting for all sessions to age out or without resetting the NetScreen device.

Lastly, ScreenOS 3.1.0 and later allow the administrator to enable firewall protections, including port scan protections, on any interface. 

NetScreen recommends all customers to upgrade to the latest version of ScreenOS supported by their hardware and then to enable one or all of the above features to minimize the likelihood of being affected by this issue.

The latest currently available versions of ScreenOS at the time of this writing for each NetScreen device are:

Hardware,                ScreenOS release
NetScreen-5,                     2.6.1r6
NetScreen-5XP,           3.0.1r1
NetScreen-10,            3.0.1r1
NetScreen-25,            3.0.0r1
NetScreen-50,            3.0.0r1
NetScreen-100,           3.0.1r1
NetScreen-204,           3.1.0r1
NetScreen-208,           3.1.0r1
NetScreen-500,           3.1.0r1
NetScreen-1000,          2.8.0r1"

Title: (Vendor Clarifies) Re: NetScreen Firewalls Can Be Made Unresponsive By a Remote User on the Trusted Interface Side Conducting Port Scans Through the Firewall
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in NetScreen firewalls (Screen OS).  A remote user on the trusted interface can cause the interface to hang.
It is reported that a remote user on the trusted (internal) interface can conduct a port scan on an external IP address to consume available sessions on the firewall.  This can reportedly cause the entire trusted interface to become unresponsive.
Impact': A remote user on the internal (trusted) interface can cause the interface to become unresponsive.
Solution:
The vendor reports that this vulnerability was fixed in ScreenOS 2.6.1 back in September of 2001 in response to the Code Red attacks. The vendor provides the following information:

"The feature is called Source IP Session Thresholding.  This feature was implemented as a CLI command in 2.6.1r2, and has been incorporated into the WebUI starting with ScreenOS 3.1.  ScreenOS 3.1 is currently available for the NS-204, NS-208, and NS-500.

The command:

set firewall session-threshold source-ip-based [num]

limits any one source IP from the trusted side to [num] number of concurrent sessions.  Since the 5XP can support 2048 concurrent sessions, it would make sense to set the limit lower than that.  I would recommend the higher of the following two numbers as a starting point:  100, or 2048/n where n is the number of systems on your private side network.  You might want to check your flow counters to see if that's an acceptable number, and modify accordingly.

As to how long these sessions remain active is user configurable.  ScreenOS has a default setting for session inactivity timeout of 30 minutes.  Both pre-defined and custom services can be adjusted in timeout value from 1 minute to 2 days.  If you would have waited 30 minutes, your portscans to an unresponsive machine would have timed out and the sessions cleared for reuse.  If you had scanned a machine that responded to the scans (with either ICMP unreachable or RST), the session would have  closed immediately."

Title: NetScreen Firewalls Can Be Made Unresponsive By a Remote User on the Trusted Interface Side Conducting Port Scans Through the Firewall
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in NetScreen firewalls (Screen OS).  A remote user on the trusted interface can cause the interface to hang.
It is reported that a remote user on the trusted (internal) interface can conduct a port scan on an external IP address to consume available sessions on the firewall.  This can reportedly cause the entire trusted interface to become unresponsive.
Impact': A remote user on the internal (trusted) interface can cause the interface to become unresponsive.
Solution: It is reported that NetScreen has issued a fix (version 3.1).  An update to ScreenOS 3.1 is apparently available for the NetScreen 200 or 500 models and reportedly will be available for all other models on April 1, 2002.

Title: SmoothWall Firewall's Internal Configuration May Allow a Local User to Gain Access to Unauthorized Information
Description:
Security Focus reported vulnerabilities in the SmoothWall firewall version 0.9.9.  A local user may obtain hashed passwords and may obtain or edit the firewall configuration.
It is reported that that SmoothWall does not implement a shadowed password file.  A local unprivileged user could reportedly obtain a copy of the hashed passwords and attempt to decrypt them.  It is also reported that the /var/smoothwall directory containing the firewall configuration files is owned by the 'nobody' user and group.   A local user could read or modify the configuration files.

The report credits Juergen Schmidt <ju@ct.heise.de> with presenting these issues.

The vendor has responded that these observations are not relevant because there is only a single user account that can access the shell, and that is the 'root' user.  There are no other local users.
Impact':
A local user could obtain the hashed passwords and attempt to decrypt them.  A local user could view and potentially modify the firewall configuration.

The vendor disputes these issues, indicating that the only user that can access the shell is 'root', so there could be no unprivileged local users.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fix for the non-shadowed password file issue (Patches 0.9.9-20020114-fixes7), available at:

http://www.smoothwall.org/gpl/get/download/patches/0.9.9-20020114-fixes7.html

The vendor disputes the configuration file issue, stating that the only user that can access the shell is the 'root' user and that no unprivileged users can access the shell.

Title: (Cisco Clarifies and Issues Fix) Re: Cisco PIX Firewall That Requires AAA/TACACS+ Authentication Can Be Crashed By Initiating Many Remote Connections Through The Firewall
Version(s): versions 4.0 up to and including 4.4(8), 5.0(3), 5.1(3), 5.2(2), and 5.3(1) with configurations using AAA authentication
Description:
Datanet Systems reported a denial of service vulnerability in the Cisco PIX Firewall version 5.1 that can be exploited by overwhelming the firewall with authentication requests.
It is reported that when AAA authentication services are configured, a remote user from a single source address can consume all of the authentication resources, preventing other users from authenticating.  Only new authentication requests are prevented.  Existing traffic continues to be processed by the firewall.

The vendor notes that vulnerable systems will have configuration lines that begin:

pixfirewall#  aaa authentication ...

Cisco has assigned this vulnerability Cisco bug ID CSCdt92339.
Impact': A remote user can cause the firewall's authentication services to crash.
Solution: Recent versions of the PIX Firewall reportedly set a maximum limit of three open authentication requests per user, but this has been modified to allow the administrator to adjust the limit.  Patches are available for vulnerable systems.  See the Vendor URL for details.

Title: Cisco Secure PIX Firewall SMTP Mail Filtering Flaw Lets Remote Users Bypass the Firewall's SMTP Command Filtering Feature
Version(s): 6.0(1), 5.2(5) and 5.2(4); when using SMTP Mail service
Description:
Cisco reported a vulnerability in their Secure PIX Firewall SMTP mailguard function.  A remote user can communicate through the firewall using valid SMTP commands that will bypass the firewall's SMTP command filtering.
Cisco reports that this is similar to a vulnerability reported in 2000 that had been corrected by now exists again.  In the previous vulnerability, a remote user could send SMTP commands in a certain order to bypass the filtering restrictions.  For example, if the DATA command was sent before the RCPT command, the firewall would stop filtering after the end of the DATA section, allowing subsequent commands to pass.

Cisco reports that users with configurations similar to the following may be vulnerable:

     fixup protocol smtp 25
     and either
     conduit permit tcp host 192.168.0.1 eq 25 any
     or
     conduit permit tcp 192.168.0.1 255.255.255.0 eq 25 any
     or
     access-list 100 permit tcp any host 192.168.0.1 eq 25
     access-group 100 in interface outside

This vulnerability has been assigned Cisco bug ID CSCdu47003.
Impact': A remote user could send SMTP commands through the PIX Firewall, bypassing SMTP command restrictions.
Solution: Cisco has issued a fix, available to all customers.  For information on obtaining the fix, read the Cisco advisory (see the Vendor URL).

Title: (WatchGuard Issues Fix) Re: WatchGuard Firebox Firewall SMTP Proxy Fails to Block E-mail Based Executables and Scripts in Certain Conditions
Description:
It is reported that the WatchGuard Firebox SMTP Proxy fails to properly block certain MIME attachments when configured to block them.  This allows a remote user to pass a potentially hazardous e-mail attachment through the firewall.
The firewall reportedly includes an SMTP proxy that allows for the blocking of e-mail attachments by MIME type and by file extension. It is reported that, under certain conditions, this feature will fail to proerly block the attachments.

The vulnerability is believed to be due to improper identification of e-mail attachments when the MIME boundary contains certain characters.  If the MIME boundary ends with two dashes, the vulnerability can reportedly be triggered.

Some example exploit configurations are included in the Source Message.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user can send a potentially hazardous e-mail attachment through the firewall even if the firewall is configured to block the attachment.
Solution: Upgrade to 4.61.

Title: WatchGuard Firebox Firewall SMTP Proxy Fails to Block E-mail Based Executables and Scripts in Certain Conditions
Description:
It is reported that the WatchGuard Firebox SMTP Proxy fails to properly block certain MIME attachments when configured to block them.  This allows a remote user to pass a potentially hazardous e-mail attachment through the firewall.
The firewall reportedly includes an SMTP proxy that allows for the blocking of e-mail attachments by MIME type and by file extension. It is reported that, under certain conditions, this feature will fail to proerly block the attachments.

The vulnerability is believed to be due to improper identification of e-mail attachments when the MIME boundary contains certain characters.  If the MIME boundary ends with two dashes, the vulnerability can reportedly be triggered.

Some example exploit configurations are included in the Source Message.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user can send a potentially hazardous e-mail attachment through the firewall even if the firewall is configured to block the attachment.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: (Vendor Releases Fix) Re: SpearHead's NetGAP Security Appliance Allows Remote Users to Bypass the Web Content Filtering Engine
Description:
A vulnerability has been reported in the NetGAP security appliance's content checking engine that allows remote users to bypass the content filtering.
The NetGAP content checking engine reportedly can filter specific file types being downloaded via HTTP.

If a remote user sends a request that uses Unicode encoding techniques, the filtering engine can be bypassed.  The NetGap  URL filter apparently does not properly interpret URLs that contain Unicode characters.
Impact': A remote user can specify a web URL for a file download that will not be subject to the NetGAP filtering engine.
Solution: The problem has reportedly been fixed in build 78 of the NetGAP software.

Title: SpearHead's NetGAP Security Appliance Allows Remote Users to Bypass the Web Content Filtering Engine
Description:
A vulnerability has been reported in the NetGAP security appliance's content checking engine that allows remote users to bypass the content filtering.
The NetGAP content checking engine reportedly can filter specific file types being downloaded via HTTP.

If a remote user sends a request that uses Unicode encoding techniques, the filtering engine can be bypassed.  The NetGap  URL filter apparently does not properly interpret URLs that contain Unicode characters.
Impact': A remote user can specify a web URL for a file download that will not be subject to the NetGAP filtering engine.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.  The vendor has reportedly acknowledged the vulnerability and will release a patch shortly.

Title: (Interim Vendor Message) Re: Cisco PIX Firewall That Requires AAA/TACACS+ Authentication Can Be Crashed By Initiating Many Remote Connections Through The Firewall
Description:
Datanet Systems reported a denial of service vulnerability in the Cisco PIX Firewall version 5.1 that can be exploited by overwhelming the firewall with authentication requests.
A remote user can cause a PIX Firewall 515 or 520 running verion 5.1.4 to crash if the firewall is using aaa authentication with a TACACS+ Server.  By generating a large number of sessions (on the order of 425) that require authentication from either the inside or outside interfaces, the firewall can be made to crash.

Details of the configuration required to exercise this vulnerability are contained in the source message.
Impact': A remote user can cause the PIX firewall to crash.
Solution: Cisco issued an interim message indicating that they are attempting to recreate the problem in their labs.  Cisco recommends not using the 5.1 code base due to another issue with version 5.1.x.  Apparently, the vulnerabiliyt does not exist in the more recent code base.

Title: Cisco PIX Firewall That Requires AAA/TACACS+ Authentication Can Be Crashed By Initiating Many Remote Connections Through The Firewall
Description:
Datanet Systems reported a denial of service vulnerability in the Cisco PIX Firewall version 5.1 that can be exploited by overwhelming the firewall with authentication requests.
A remote user can cause a PIX Firewall 515 or 520 running verion 5.1.4 to crash if the firewall is using aaa authentication with a TACACS+ Server.  By generating a large number of sessions (on the order of 425) that require authentication from either the inside or outside interfaces, the firewall can be made to crash.

Details of the configuration required to exercise this vulnerability are contained in the source message.
Impact': A remote user can cause the PIX firewall to crash.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.  The author of the report indicates that version 5.3.1 is not vulnerable.

Title: Watchguard Firebox II Firewall Can Be Crashed By Remote Users With a Burst of Malformed Packets
Description:
Defcom Labs reported an vulnerability in the Watchguard Firebox II that could allow remote users to cause the firewall to crash.  In many cases, there will be no trace of the attack in the log files.
Defcom Labs reports that the Linux-based kernel in the Watchguard Firebox II does not properly process certain malformed packets and, if subjected to a traffic burst of approximately 10,000 of these malformed packets, the kernel will crash or reboot.  The malformed packets may be both TCP and ICMP packets.  The burst rate necessary to trigger this vulnerability was reported to be approximately 1 Mbps.

Apparently, the firewall will not log the attack in most instances and, when the firewall crashes, some networking functions continue to perform on the firewall.

See Defcom Labs Advisory def-2001-18.
Impact': A remote user with the ability to submit 1 Mbps of malformed packets to the firewall can cause it to crash or reboot.
Solution: Upgrade to version 4.6.

Title: NetScreen Firewalls Allow Unauthorized Packets Through the Firewall to the DMZ
Description:
Netscreen announced a vulnerability in its NetScreen-10 and NetScreen-100 systems that, under certain circumstances, allows unauthorized packets to reach the "DMZ" network.
Netscreen issued an advisory regarding a vulnerability (bug ID 8166) in all current versions of ScreenOS software (ScreenOS release 1.64, 1.66, 2.01, and 2.5) for NetScreen-10 and NetScreen-100 systems.  

Under certain circumstances, traffic that is otherwise configured to be blocked by the security policy configuration is able to reach the "DMZ" network.  The vendor notes that traffic cannot reach the trusted network.

It is reported that The vulnerability only exists after specific traffic patterns have been present for some time.  Some packets (but not all packets) are then allowed to pass to the DMZ network.
Impact': Some unauthorized packets may be allowed to pass through to the DMZ network interface.
Solution: The vendor has released a fix.

Title: (Cisco Responds) Re: Cisco PIX Has Multiple Vulnerabilities: It May Allow Certain Spoofed Packets to Pass Through The Firewall and May Allow Denial of Service in Certain Limited Situations
Description:
Cisco PIX reportedly contains two vulnerabilities:  one that allows a remote attacker to send certain IP packets with spoofed addresses through the firewall, and one that allows a remote attacker to cause a denial of service condition in certain restricted situations.
Cisco makes a detailed response to the reported vulnerabilities.  In short, the vulnerabilities have either already been corrected in an interim release or have been assigned Cisco Bug IDs and will be fixed in a future release.  

Please read the source message below for the details.
Impact': A remote attacker may be able to send certain spoofed packets through the firewall under certain configurations.  A remote attacker with some level of authorization may be able to cause the PIX's memory to be consumed.
Solution: Cisco has fixed some of the issues and plans to fix the remaining issues.  Please read the source message for the details.

Title: Cisco PIX Has Multiple Vulnerabilities: It May Allow Certain Spoofed Packets to Pass Through The Firewall and May Allow Denial of Service in Certain Limited Situations
Description:
Cisco PIX reportedly contains two vulnerabilities:  one that allows a remote attacker to send certain IP packets with spoofed addresses through the firewall, and one that allows a remote attacker to cause a denial of service condition in certain restricted situations.
When SSH or PPTP are enabled from the exteral-side, an attacker on the external interface may be able to send spoofed SSH or PPTP packets through the firewall.

The denial of service vulnerability requires either an authorized administrator or an attacker whose IP address is in the PIX's telnet enable list.  In this case, internal-side users who are in the telnet enable list can cause PIX memory to be consumed by sending data to the Cisco PIX Secure Database Manager port (1467/tcp).
Impact': A remote attacker may be able to send certain spoofed packets through the firewall under certain configurations.  A remote attacker with some level of authorization may be able to cause the PIX's memory to be consumed.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.
